texts.shortText: Dark, flattened flies with a plain black thorax, clear grey wings and hairy legs. Best identified by their habitat, which is restricted to beaches, especially those where large amounts of kelp are washed ashore. Can attain very high densities when food is abundant. Distinguished from the other common kelp fly in the region (Fucellia capensis) by the lack of longitudinal stripes on the thorax.

Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: Western Cape, restricted to the upper shore.

Associated with draft seaweeds on the coastline. Reluctant to fly and when disturbed typically remain close to the sand, moving only a few metres before settling again. Can swarm in large numbers when conditions are favourable and become a nuisance to beach users. Larvae found in large numbers in moist piles of rotting kelp.
Adults probably feed on the mucus exuded by rotting kelps. Larva consume decomposing kelps and may be important agents in their decay and disappearance from beaches.

Eggs are laid singly on the surfaces of kelps cast up on the driftline. The decomposition of the kelp keeps temperatures elevated and may speed up larval development.  Pupae are often washed out on the next set off high spring tides and may be found in large numbers along the driftline. Larval and pupal stages each about two weeks in duration.
Often occur at the same sites as another kelp fly Fucellia capensis, which has very similar habits, but can be distinguished by having four pale longitudinal stripes along the thorax.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town.(p. 78).

Picker, MD, Griffiths, CL & Weaving, A (2019). Field Guide to Insects of South Africa. Third Edition. Struik Nature, Cape Town, 527 pp. (p. 346).
